> If you have a web or mail server, you should disable support for export cipher suites and generate a unique 2048-bit Diffie-Hellman group. 

https://weakdh.org/

I don't expect we'll be able to generate a unique 2048-bit Diffie-Helman group, since we're on Heroku. We're dependent on them anyway to disable the old cipher suite.

`TLS_DHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA` is the cipher suite that SSL Labs [flags](https://www.ssllabs.com/ssltest/analyze.html?d=gratipay.com&s=54.83.192.33&latest) as bad. Amazon's latest [security policy](http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ElasticLoadBalancing/latest/DeveloperGuide/elb-security-policy-table.html), 2015-05, drops `DHE-RSA-AES128-SHA` and `DHE-DSS-AES128-SHA`. From their [announcement](https://forums.aws.amazon.com/ann.jspa?annID=3061):

> At present ELB load balancers use a 1024-bit DHE key size. This size is also being updated to 2048-bit, however we recommend using ECDHE where available due to greater cryptographic strength and speedier operation.

Sent to Heroku:

> Can you provide a timeframe for upgrading to the 2015-05 [security policy](http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ElasticLoadBalancing/latest/DeveloperGuide/elb-security-policy-table.html)? We're interested in dropping `DHE-{RSA,DSS}-AES128-SHA` in order to mitigate [Logjam](https://weakdh.org/).
>
Thanks! :-)

https://help.heroku.com/tickets/252865

Them:

> I can update this for you now. Would you like it done on just your `gratipay` app or are there others you would also like updated? Note that we can only update this for apps using the SSL Endpoint add-on.

From Heroku:

>
If you see any trouble with that please let us know.
Removal of bad ciphers confirmed in both SSL Labs and sslyze.

@hammad You're right. I've sent the following email to support@hackerone.com:

Subject: more control over glory?

> Greetings!
>
We've just completed and have requested publication of [our first bug](https://hackerone.com/reports/76303) on HackerOne. The platform is great! In fact, we've decided to make HackerOne our primary security queue.
>
However, we're having a couple issues with recognizing researchers.
>
First, we have decided to maintain our old email-based program as a legacy system, and to file bugs received via email over on HackerOne. This means that one of our security team—in the presenting case, me—is credited with the report instead of the original researcher. Our [policy](http://inside.gratipay.com/howto/handle-security-issues) calls for inviting the researcher to join HackerOne if they haven't already, but I'm not seeing a way that we can reassign recognition to them instead of us.
>
Second, we'd like to recognize *all* researchers that contribute to a report, not just the first. In the presenting case, we had a second researcher who was reporting the same basic vulnerability but provided helpful additional information. We'd like to encourage collaboration amongst researchers who are willing to work with us, and to that end we'd like to recognize multiple contributors to a single bug.
>
It seems that these issues could be addressed if we had more direct control over the process of recognizing researchers. Is that a possibility?
>
Thanks! :-)

@hammad I've reopened and re-resolved this ticket until we can sort out proper recognition with HackerOne support. I want to disclose this issue because we have a policy of being as open and transparent as possible and this ticket contains a record of our work, which I want to be public.

Hi,

I would like to remain anonymous. Is there any way to make this happen?

Thanks

HackerOne's [advice](https://hackerone.com/disclosure-guidelines) is for you to use a pseudonym:

> If a Researcher prefers to remain anonymous, we encourage them to submit under a pseudonym.

It's probably too late for you to do that now, unless you wanted to try to alter your HackerOne profile to remove personally identifying information.

Response from HackerOne re: reputation reassignment:

> That's awesome! I'm looking forward to see #76303 be publicly disclosed!
>
We can import reports for you, we link the reporter to a researcher by email. They will receive reputation and be listed on your program's HOF. I'm curious why you don't motivate researchers to report issues directly on HackerOne? We have some nice tools that help you identify signal and we have even more tools planned to help you respond to reports even faster!
>
About recognizing researchers in your program. What we do in our own program: we add the researcher who submitted the duplicate report to the original report. You can simply do this by closing the report as a duplicate an tick the `Add _x_ to the original report` checkbox). The duplicate report gets `+2` instead of `+7` reputation, this can be fixed easily by reopening the duplicate and closing it as a resolved bug. If your program receives a lot of reports where multiple researchers are working on the same report, we could look into a more elegant solution. But so far we don't see much reports with true collaboration between researchers.
>
Hopefully this helps! If you have any further questions, please let us know.

My reply:

>Thanks for the helpful reply, Willian.
>
>> I'm curious why you don't motivate researchers to report issues directly on HackerOne?
>
[We do](https://hackerone.com/gratipay)! The issue in question (#76303) is one of a handful that we manually migrated over from our old legacy security queue just last week. I guess it would've been better for us to run that through you. :-( Are you able to manually update the reporters for us if I point out the relevant tickets to you?
>
Good to know about the +2 effect of duplicates on reputation. I expect that will address our needs there just fine.

> If you send us a csv with the report id and the researcher's email we will update the original reporter (if the email is known).

CSV sent.

@hammad HackerOne support has updated tickets so now you are the reporter, so I am re-requesting disclosure. Re: reputation: "My initial plan was to also update the reputation records but this migration was a bit too complex. So we've to wait for the next reputation recalculation for the right +7s."
